4.label: The balances on your accounts are too high compared to loan amounts
4.description: The balances on your accounts are high compared to the original loan amounts, lowering your score.
4.tip: Paying down the balances on your accounts will benefit your score.

5.label: Too many of the delinquencies on your accounts are recent
5.description: A delinquency is a payment that was made 30 or more days late.  Too many late payments occurred recently on some of your accounts.  Late payments are a proven indicator of increased risk.  People with late payments are at risk of being overextended, putting existing credit with lenders at risk.
5.tip: Paying bills on time every month is important to maintaining a good credit score.  If you remain behind with any payments, bring them current as soon as possible, and then make future payments on time. Over time, this will have a positive impact on your score.

6.label: You have too many accounts that were opened recently
6.description: Because too many of your accounts were opened recently, the history on those new accounts is not long enough to provide sufficient payment and account history to demonstrate responsible behavior on those accounts.  In addition, having multiple accounts that are relatively new is seen as a higher risk because of the possibility of becoming overextended, which can then lead to late payments or defaulting on the account.
6.tip: Use your existing credit responsibly and make your payments on time. Your credit score will benefit as you make payments on time and manage the accounts in a responsible fashion. Manage your credit wisely by planning ahead for your credit needs and avoid applying for more credit than you need.

7.label: You have too many delinquent or derogatory accounts
7.description: You have had too many accounts with payments that are at least 30 days late and/or on which a lender has reported a derogatory status.  Late payments are a proven indicator of increased risk.  People with late payments are at risk of being overextended, putting existing credit with lenders at risk.
7.tip: Paying bills on time every month is important to maintaining a good credit score.  If you remain behind with any payments, bring them current as soon as possible, and then make future payments on time. Over time, this will have a positive impact on your score.

8.label: You have either very few loans or too many loans with recent delinquencies
8.description: You have had too many accounts with late payments or do not have enough loans to provide sufficient information about your credit behaviors. Late payments are a proven indicator of increased risk.  People with late payments are at risk of being overextended, putting existing credit with lenders at risk.
8.tip: Paying bills on time every month is important to maintaining a good credit score.  If you remain behind with any payments, bring them current as soon as possible, and then make future payments on time. Over time, this will have a positive impact on your score.

9.label: The worst payment status on your accounts is delinquent or derogatory
9.description: Your credit file is showing an account with a payment that was at least 30 days late and/or on which a lender has reported a derogatory status.  Late payments are a proven indicator of increased risk.  People with late payments are at risk of being overextended, putting existing credit with lenders at risk.
9.tip: Paying bills on time every month is important to maintaining a good credit score.  If you remain behind with any payments, bring them current as soon as possible, and then make future payments on time. Over time, this will have a positive impact on your score.

10.label: You have either very few loans or too many loans with delinquencies
10.description: You have had too many accounts with late payments or do not have enough loans to provide sufficient information about your credit behaviors. Late payments are a proven indicator of increased risk.  People with late payments are at risk of being overextended, putting existing credit with lenders at risk.
10.tip: Paying bills on time every month is important to maintaining a good credit score.  If you remain behind with any payments, bring them current as soon as possible, and then make future payments on time. Over time, this will have a positive impact on your score.

11.label: The total of your delinquent or derogatory account balances is too high
11.description: The total of the balances is high on your accounts with late payments or on which a lender has reported the account derogatory. Late payments are a proven indicator of risk.  When credit line balances approach credit limits, risk is further increased because you don\'t have much credit available should it be needed, creating a greater chance of becoming overextended.
11.tip: Paying bills on time every month is important to maintaining a good credit score.  If you remain behind with any payments, bring them current as soon as possible, and then make future payments on time.  Whenever possible, pay down balances on your accounts.  Over time these actions will benefit your score.

12.label: The date that you opened your oldest account is too recent
12.description: Your oldest account is still too recent.  A credit file containing older accounts will have a positive impact on your credit score because it demonstrates that you are experienced managing credit.
12.tip: Don\'t open more accounts than you actually need.  Research shows that new accounts indicate greater risk.  Your score will benefit as your accounts get older.

13.label: Your most recently opened account is too new
13.description: The account that you opened most recently is still too new.  A credit file containing older accounts will have a positive impact on your credit score because it demonstrates that you are experienced managing credit.
13.tip: Don\'t open more accounts than you actually need.  Research shows that new accounts indicate greater risk, especially if overall account history isn\'t long.  Your score will benefit as your accounts get older.

14.label: Lack of sufficient credit history
14.description: Your credit file does not contain enough information about your use of credit.  A credit file with older accounts and/or more accounts reflects more experience with handling credit and can have a positive impact on your credit score.
14.tip: Maintaining open and active credit accounts in good standing can help improve your credit score.

15.label: Newest delinquent or derogatory payment status on your accounts is too recent
15.description: You have an account that had a late payment or on which a lender has reported a derogatory status.  Your credit file shows that this event occurred too recently.  Late payments are a proven indicator of increased risk.  People with late payments are at risk of being overextended, putting existing credit with lenders at risk.
15.tip: Paying bills on time every month is important to maintaining a good credit score.  If you remain behind with any payments, bring them current as soon as possible, and then make future payments on time.

16.label: The total of all balances on your open accounts is too high
16.description: The total that you owe on all your accounts is high.  Maintaining high balances has proven to be risky behavior because you don\'t have much credit available should it be needed, creating a greater chance of becoming overextended.  People with the highest credit scores keep their account balances low.
16.tip: Whenever possible, pay down balances on your accounts.  Over time, this will have a positive impact on your score.

17.label: Balances on previously delinquent accounts are too high compared to loan amts
17.description: You\'ve been late on at least one payment in the past, and the balances on the accounts that had late payments are high compared to the original loan amount or the credit limit on a revolving account.  Late payments are a proven indicator of risk.  When balances are close to the original loan amount or approach credit limits, risk is further increased because you don\'t have much credit available should it be needed, creating a greater chance of becoming overextended.  People with the best scores have no late payments and keep their balances low.
17.tip: Paying bills on time every month is important to maintaining a good credit score.  If you remain behind with any payments, bring them current as soon as possible, and then make future payments on time.  Whenever possible, pay down balances on your accounts.  Over time these actions will have a positive impact on your score.

18.label: Total of balances on accounts never late is too high compared to loan amounts
18.description: You have some accounts in your credit file with balances that are high compared to the original loan amount or the limit on a revolving account.  The good news is that you\'ve never been late on these accounts.  Maintaining high balances has proven to be risky behavior because you don\'t have much credit available should it be needed, creating a greater chance of becoming overextended.  People with the highest credit scores keep their account balances low.
18.tip: Whenever possible, pay down balances on your accounts.  Over time, this will have a positive impact on your score.

21.label: No open accounts in your credit file
21.description: The VantageScore credit score model relies on information in your credit files at the three national credit reporting companies (Equifax, Experian and TransUnion) to generate your score.  Because you have no open accounts, your credit file does not contain enough information about your use of credit.  A mix of different types of open and active credit accounts can have a positive impact on your credit score.
21.tip: Maintaining open and active credit accounts in good standing can help improve your credit score.

22.label: No recently reported account information
22.description: The VantageScore credit score model relies on information in your credit files at the three national credit reporting companies (Equifax, Experian and TransUnion) to generate your score.  Because you have no accounts where a lender has reported recent activity, your credit file does not contain enough information about your use of credit.  A mix of different types of open and active credit accounts with can have a positive impact on your credit score.
22.tip: Maintaining open and active credit accounts in good standing can help improve your credit score.

23.label: Lack of sufficient relevant account information
23.description: The VantageScore credit score model relies on information in your credit files at the three national credit reporting companies (Equifax, Experian and TransUnion) to generate your score.  Your credit file does not have enough credit behavior information about your loans.  A mix of different types of open and active credit accounts can have a positive impact on your credit score.
23.tip: Maintaining open and active credit accounts in good standing can help improve your credit score.

29.label: Too many of your open bankcard or revolving accounts have a balance
29.description: Bankcard accounts include credit cards and charge cards from a bank and are frequently revolving accounts.  Revolving accounts allow you to carry a balance and your monthly payment will vary, based on the amount of your balance.  Carrying a balance on too many bankcards and revolving accounts is an indicator of increased risk.  People who carry balances on multiple bankcards or revolving accounts have reduced available credit to use if needed, creating a greater chance of becoming overextended.
29.tip: Pay down your existing balances, and then pay your balance in full each month as often as possible.

30.label: Too few of your bankcard or other revolving accounts have high limits
30.description: Bankcard accounts include credit cards and charge cards from a bank and are frequently revolving accounts.  Revolving accounts allow you to carry a balance and your monthly payment will vary, based on the amount of your balance.  Having too few accounts with high credit limits is an indicator that you lack available credit.  Having higher limits gives you access to credit without seeking new loans or becoming overextended _ which are triggers for higher risk.
30.tip: Use credit responsibly and always make payments on time with your existing accounts.  After a period of successfully managing your accounts, you can seek increases to your credit limit.

31.label: Too many bankcard or other revolving accounts were opened recently
31.description: Bankcard accounts include credit cards and charge cards from a bank and are frequently revolving accounts.  Revolving accounts allow you to carry a balance and your monthly payment will vary, based on the amount of your balance.  Opening multiple bankcards or other revolving accounts in a relatively short period of time is a proven indicator of increased risk because the history on those new accounts is not long enough to provide sufficient payment and account information to demonstrate responsible behavior on those accounts.  In addition, having multiple accounts that are relatively new is seen as a higher risk because of the possibility of becoming overextended, which can then lead to late payments or defaulting on the account.
31.tip: Use your existing credit responsibly and make your payments on time. Your credit score will benefit as you make payments on time and manage the accounts in a responsible fashion. Manage your credit wisely by planning ahead for your credit needs so you can avoid applying for more credit than you need.

32.label: Balances on bankcard or revolving accounts too high compared to credit limits
32.description: Bankcard accounts include credit cards and charge cards from a bank and are frequently revolving accounts.  Revolving accounts allow you to carry a balance and your monthly payment will vary, based on the amount of your balance.  You have bankcard or revolving accounts in your credit file with balances that are high compared to the credit limit on the account, which is a proven indicator of increased risk.
32.tip: Pay down balances on your accounts and keep them below 30% of the total credit limit on that account.  Over time this will have a positive impact on your score.

33.label: Your worst bankcard or revolving account status is delinquent or derogatory
33.description: Bankcard accounts include credit cards and charge cards from a bank and are frequently revolving accounts.  Revolving accounts allow you to carry a balance and your monthly payment will vary, based on the amount of your balance.  Your credit file is showing a bankcard or revolving account with a payment that was at least 30 days late and/or an account on which a lender has reported a derogatory status.  Late payments are a proven indicator of increased risk.  People with late payments are at risk of being overextended, putting existing credit with lenders at risk.
33.tip: Paying bills on time every month is important to maintaining a good credit score.  If you remain behind with any payments, bring them current as soon as possible, and then make future payments on time.  Over time, this will have a positive impact on your score.

34.label: Total of all balances on bankcard or revolving accounts is too high
34.description: Bankcard accounts include credit cards and charge cards from a bank and are frequently revolving accounts.  Revolving accounts allow you to carry a balance and your monthly payment will vary, based on the amount of your balance.  The total combined amount you owe on all of your bankcards and revolving accounts is high, a sign of increased risk. People who carry balances on multiple bankcards or other revolving accounts have reduced available credit to use if needed, creating a greater chance of becoming overextended.
34.tip: Pay down the balances on your accounts. Ideally, the balance on any revolving account should be 30% or less of the total credit limit on that account.

35.label: Your highest bankcard or revolving account balance is too high
35.description: Bankcard accounts include credit cards and charge cards from a bank and are frequently revolving accounts.  Revolving accounts allow you to carry a balance and your monthly payment will vary, based on the amount of your balance.  You have a bankcard or revolving account in your credit file with a high balance, a sign of increased risk. People who carry balances on bankcards or other revolving accounts have reduced available credit to use if needed, creating a greater chance of becoming overextended.
35.tip: Pay down the balances on your accounts. Ideally, the balance on any revolving account should be 30% or less of the total credit limit on that account.

36.label: Your largest credit limit on open bankcard or revolving accounts is too low
36.description: Bankcard accounts include credit cards and charge cards from a bank and are frequently revolving accounts.  Revolving accounts allow you to carry a balance and your monthly payment will vary, based on the amount of your balance.  The largest credit limit among all the open bankcard or revolving accounts in your credit file is low.  Having higher limits gives you access to credit without seeking new loans or becoming overextended _ which are triggers for higher risk.
36.tip: Use credit responsibly and always make payments on time with your existing accounts.  After a period of successfully managing your accounts, you can seek increases to your credit limit.

39.label: Available credit on your open bankcard or revolving accounts is too low
39.description: Bankcard accounts include credit cards and charge cards from a bank and are frequently revolving accounts.  Revolving accounts allow you to carry a balance and your monthly payment will vary, based on the amount of your balance.  The amount of credit you have available to use on your open bankcards or revolving accounts is low.  Having higher limits gives you access to credit without seeking new loans or becoming overextended _ which are triggers for higher risk.
39.tip: Use credit responsibly and always make payments on time with your existing accounts.  After a period of successfully managing your accounts, you can seek increases to your credit limit.

40.label: The date you opened your oldest bankcard or revolving account is too recent
40.description: Bankcard accounts include credit cards and charge cards from a bank and are frequently revolving accounts.  Revolving accounts allow you to carry a balance and your monthly payment will vary, based on the amount of your balance.  Your oldest bankcard or revolving account is still too new.  A credit file containing older accounts will have a positive impact on your credit score because it demonstrates that you are experienced managing credit.
40.tip: Don\'t open more accounts than you actually need.  Research shows that new accounts indicate greater risk.  Your score will benefit as your accounts get older.

42.label: The date you opened your newest bankcard or revolving account is too recent
42.description: Bankcard accounts include credit cards and charge cards from a bank and are frequently revolving accounts.  Revolving accounts allow you to carry a balance and your monthly payment will vary, based on the amount of your balance.  The bankcard or revolving account that you opened most recently is still too new.  A credit file containing older accounts will have a positive impact on your credit score because it demonstrates that you are experienced managing credit.
42.tip: Don\'t open more accounts than you actually need.  Research shows that new accounts indicate greater risk, especially if overall account history isn\'t long.  Your score will benefit as your accounts get older.

43.label: Lack of sufficient credit history on bankcard or revolving accounts
43.description: Bankcard accounts include credit cards and charge cards from a bank and are frequently revolving accounts.  Revolving accounts allow you to carry a balance and your monthly payment will vary, based on the amount of your balance.  Your credit file does not contain enough information about your use of bankcards or revolving accounts.  A credit file with older accounts and/or more accounts reflects more experience with handling credit and can have a positive impact on your credit score.
43.tip: Maintaining open and active credit accounts in good standing can help improve your credit score.

44.label: Too many bankcard or revolving accounts with delinquent or derogatory status
44.description: Bankcard accounts include credit cards and charge cards from a bank and are frequently revolving accounts.  Revolving accounts allow you to carry a balance and your monthly payment will vary, based on the amount of your balance.  You have had too many bankcard or revolving accounts with payments that are at least 30 days late and/or on which a lender has reported a derogatory status.  People with late payments are at risk of being overextended, putting existing credit with lenders at risk.
44.tip: Paying bills on time every month is important to maintaining a good credit score.  If you remain behind with any payments, bring them current as soon as possible, and then make future payments on time. Over time this will have a positive impact on your score.

45.label: Total balances too high on delinquent/derogatory bankcard or revolving accts
45.description: Bankcard accounts include credit cards and charge cards from a bank and are frequently revolving accounts.  Revolving accounts allow you to carry a balance and your monthly payment will vary, based on the amount of your balance.  The total of the balances is high on your bankcard or revolving accounts with late payments or on which a lender has reported a derogatory.  Late payments are a proven indicator of risk.  When credit line balances approach credit limits, risk is further increased because you don\'t have much credit available should it be needed, creating a greater chance of becoming overextended.
45.tip: Paying bills on time every month is important to maintaining a good credit score.  If you remain behind with any payments, bring them current as soon as possible, and then make future payments on time.  Whenever possible, pay down balances on your accounts.  Over time these actions will benefit your score.

47.label: No open bankcard or revolving accounts in your credit file
47.description: Bankcard accounts include credit cards and charge cards from a bank and are frequently revolving accounts.  Revolving accounts allow you to carry a balance and your monthly payment will vary, based on the amount of your balance.   The VantageScore credit score model relies on information in your credit files at the three national credit reporting companies (Equifax, Experian and TransUnion) to generate your score.  Because you have no open bankcards or revolving accounts, your credit file does not contain enough information about your use of credit.  A mix of different types of open and active credit accounts, including bankcards and other revolving accounts, can have a positive impact on your credit score.

48.label: No bankcard or revolving recently reported account information
48.description: Bankcard accounts include credit cards and charge cards from a bank and are frequently revolving accounts.  Revolving accounts allow you to carry a balance and your monthly payment will vary, based on the amount of your balance.  The VantageScore credit score model relies on information in your credit files at the three national credit reporting companies (Equifax, Experian and TransUnion) to generate your score.  Because you have no bankcard or revolving accounts where a lender has reported recent activity, your credit file does not contain enough information about your use of this kind of credit.  A mix of different types of open and active credit accounts, including bankcards and other revolving accounts, can have a positive impact on your credit score.

49.label: Lack of sufficient relevant bankcard or revolving account information
49.description: Bankcard accounts include credit cards and charge cards from a bank and are frequently revolving accounts.  Revolving accounts allow you to carry a balance and your monthly payment will vary, based on the amount of your balance.  The VantageScore credit score model relies on information in your credit files at the three national credit reporting companies (Equifax, Experian and TransUnion) to generate your score.  Your credit file does not have enough credit behavior information about your bankcard or revolving accounts. A mix of different types of open and active credit accounts, including bankcard and other revolving accounts, can have a positive impact on your credit score.
49.tip: Maintaining open and active credit accounts in good standing can help improve your credit score.

53.label: The worst status on your real estate accounts is delinquent or derogatory
53.description: A real estate loan can be a first mortgage, a home equity loan, or home equity line of credit.  Your credit file is showing a real estate account with a payment that was at least 30 days late and/or on which a lender has reported a derogatory status.  Late payments are a proven indicator of increased risk.  People with late payments are at risk of being overextended, putting existing credit with lenders at risk.
53.tip: Paying bills on time every month is important to maintaining a good credit score.  If you remain behind with any payments, bring them current as soon as possible, and then make future payments on time. Over time this will have a positive impact on your score.

54.label: The amount of balance paid down on your open real estate accounts is too low
54.description: A real estate loan can be a first mortgage, a home equity loan, or home equity line of credit.  The amount that has been paid down on your open real estate accounts is low.  People who haven\'t paid down much of their mortgage or other real estate loans are higher credit risks than people who have.
54.tip: As monthly real estate payments are made, a portion of the outstanding principal balance is reduced, benefitting your score.  Whenever possible, further pay down balances on your real estate accounts.  Over time this will also have a positive impact on your score.

55.label: Open real estate account balances are too high compared to their loan amounts
55.description: A real estate loan can be a first mortgage, a home equity loan, or home equity line of credit.  The outstanding balances on open real estate accounts remain high compared to the original loan amounts.  People who haven\'t paid down much of their mortgage or other real estate loans are higher credit risks than people who have.
55.tip: As monthly real estate payments are made, a portion of the outstanding principal balance is reduced, benefitting your score.  Whenever possible, further pay down balances on your real estate accounts.  Over time this will also have a positive impact on your score.

57.label: Too many real estate accounts with delinquent or derogatory payment status
57.description: A real estate loan can be a first mortgage, a home equity loan, or home equity line of credit.  You have had too many real estate accounts with payments that are at least 30 days late and/or on which a lender has reported a derogatory status. Late payments are a proven indicator of increased risk.  People with late payments are at risk of being overextended, putting existing credit with lenders at risk.
57.tip: Paying all bills on time every month is important to maintaining a good credit score.  If you remain behind with any payments, bring them current as soon as possible, and then make future payments on time. Over time this will have a positive impact on your score.

58.label: The total of all balances on your open real estate accounts is too high
58.description: A real estate loan can be a first mortgage, a home equity loan, or home equity line of credit.  The total that you owe on all of your open real estate accounts is high.  Maintaining high balances has proven to be risky behavior because you don\'t have much credit available should it be needed, creating a greater chance of becoming overextended.  People with the highest credit scores keep their account balances low.
58.tip: As monthly real estate payments are made, a portion of the outstanding principal balance is reduced, benefitting your score.  Whenever possible, further pay down balances on your real estate accounts.  Over time this will also have a positive impact on your score.

61.label: No open real estate accounts in your credit file

A mix of different types of open and active credit accounts, including real estate accounts, can have a positive impact on your credit score.

71.label: You have either very few installment loans or too many with delinquencies
71.description: An installment account is one with a fixed monthly payment for the life of the loan.  Auto loans and student loans are common examples of installment loans.  You have had too many installment accounts with late payments or do not have enough installment loans to provide sufficient information about your credit behaviors.  Late payments are a proven indicator of increased risk.  People with late payments are at risk of being overextended, putting existing credit with lenders at risk.
71.tip: Paying bills on time every month is important to maintaining a good credit score.  If you remain behind with any payments, bring them current as soon as possible, and then make future payments on time. Over time this will have a positive impact on your score.

72.label: Too many installment accounts with a delinquent or derogatory payment status
72.description: An installment account is one with a fixed monthly payment for the life of the loan.  Auto loans and student loans are common examples of installment loans.  You have had too many installment accounts that are at least 30 days late and/or on which a lender has reported a derogatory status.  Late payments are a proven indicator of increased risk. 72.tip: Paying all bills on time every month is important to maintaining a good credit score.  If you remain behind with any payments, bring them current as soon as possible, and then make future payments on time. Over time this will have a positive impact on your score.

73.label: The worst status on your installment accounts is delinquent or derogatory
73.description: An installment account is one with a fixed monthly payment for the life of the loan.  Auto loans and student loans are common examples of installment loans. 74.label: The balance amount paid down on your open installment accounts is too low

The amount that has been paid down on your open installment accounts is low. 75.label: The installment account that you opened most recently is too new

The installment account that you opened most recently is still too new. 76.label: You have insufficient credit history on installment loans
76.description: An installment account is one with a fixed monthly payment for the life of the loan.  Auto loans and student loans are common examples of installment loans.  Your credit file does not contain enough information about your use of installment loans.  A credit file with older accounts and/or more accounts reflects more experience with handling credit and can have a positive impact on your credit score.
76.tip: Maintaining open and active credit accounts in good standing can help improve your credit score.

77.label: Newest delinquent or derogatory status on installment accounts is too recent
77.description: An installment account is one with a fixed monthly payment for the life of the loan.  Auto loans and student loans are common examples of installment loans.  You have an installment account that had a late payment or on which a lender has reported a derogatory status.  Your credit file shows that this event occurred too recently.  Late payments are a proven indicator of increased risk.  People with late payments are at risk of being overextended, putting existing credit with lenders at risk.
77.tip: Paying bills on time every month is important to maintaining a good credit score.  If you remain behind with any payments, bring them current as soon as possible, and then make future payments on time.

78.label: Balances on installment accounts are too high compared to their loan amounts
78.description: An installment account is one with a fixed monthly payment for the life of the loan.  Auto loans and student loans are common examples of installment loans.  The outstanding balances on open installment accounts remain high compared to the original loan amounts.  People who haven\'t paid down much of the original amount on installment loans are higher credit risks than people who have.
78.tip: As monthly payments are made, a portion of the outstanding principal balance is reduced, benefitting your score.  Whenever possible, further pay down balances on your installment loan accounts.  Over time this will also have a positive impact on your score.

79.label: Too many of the delinquencies on your installment accounts are recent
79.description: An installment account is one with a fixed monthly payment for the life of the loan.  Auto loans and student loans are common examples of installment loans.  A delinquency is a payment that was made 30 or more days late. Too many late payments occurred recently on your installment accounts.  Late payments are a proven indicator of increased risk.  People with late payments are at risk of being overextended, putting existing credit with lenders at risk.
79.tip: Paying bills on time every month is important to maintaining a good credit score.  If you remain behind with any payments, bring them current as soon as possible, and then make future payments on time. Over time, this will have a positive impact on your score.

81.label: No open installment accounts in your credit file
81.description: An installment account is one with a fixed monthly payment for the life of the loan.  Auto loans and student loans are common examples of installment loans.  The VantageScore credit score model relies on information in your credit files at the three national credit reporting companies (Equifax, Experian and TransUnion) to generate your score.  A mix of different types of open and active credit accounts, including installment accounts, can have a positive impact on your credit score.
81.tip: Maintaining open and active credit accounts in good standing can help improve your credit score.

83.label: Lack of sufficient relevant installment account information
83.description: An installment account is one with a fixed monthly payment for the life of the loan.  Auto loans and student loans are common examples of installment loans.  The VantageScore credit score model relies on information in your credit files at the three national credit reporting companies (Equifax, Experian and TransUnion) to generate your score.  Your credit file does not contain enough information about your installment accounts.  A mix of different types of open and active credit accounts, including installment accounts, can have a positive impact on your credit score.
83.tip: Maintaining open and active credit accounts in good standing can help improve your credit score.

84.label: The number of inquiries was also a factor, but effect was not significant
84.description: If a lender runs a credit check when you apply for credit, an inquiry is reported to the credit bureaus.  This can lower your score a small amount, in this case the drop was not significant.  The VantageScore credit score model takes rate shopping, e.g., for a mortgage or car loan, into consideration.  All inquiries for mortgages, auto loans and major credit cards that appear in your credit file within a 14-day window are interpreted as a single inquiry.  Another time inquiries never count against your score is when you check your own credit or obtain your own credit score.
84.tip: Apply for credit only when you need it. If you are approved for credit, the small score drop from making an inquiry will disappear within a short time and the score will quickly benefit if you make on-time payments and manage your new account in a responsible fashion.

85.label: You have too many inquiries on your credit report.
85.description: If a lender runs a credit check when you apply for credit, an inquiry is reported to the credit bureaus.  This can lower your score a small amount, typically by 10 to 20 points.  The VantageScore credit score model takes rate shopping, e.g., for a mortgage or car loan, into consideration.  All inquiries for mortgages, auto loans and major credit cards that appear in your credit file within a 14-day window are interpreted as a single inquiry.  Another time inquiries never count against your score is when you check your own credit or obtain your own credit score.
85.tip: Apply for credit only when you need it. If you are approved for credit, the small score drop from making an inquiry will disappear within a short time and the score will quickly benefit if you make on-time payments and manage your new account in a responsible fashion.

86.label: Your credit report contains too many derogatory public records
86.description: Public records include information filed or recorded by local, state, federal or other government agencies that is available to the general public. The types of public records that can affect your credit score include legal judgments against you, or tax liens levied by a government authority.  Public records can have a significant negative impact on your credit score.
86.tip: Pay all bills on-time and satisfy all judgments.  The impact that negative items such as public records have on your credit score will diminish over time.

87.label: Your credit report contains too many unsatisfied public records
87.description: Public records include information filed or recorded by local, state, federal or other government agencies that is available to the general public. The types of public records that can affect your credit score include legal judgments against you, or tax liens levied by a government authority.  Your credit file contains public records that remain unpaid.  All public records can have a significant negative impact on your credit score.
87.tip: Pay all bills on-time and satisfy all judgments.  The impact that negative items such as public records have on your credit score will diminish over time.

88.label: One or more derogatory public records in your credit file is too recent
88.description: Public records include information filed or recorded by local, state, federal or other government agencies that is available to the general public. The types of public records that can affect your credit score include legal judgments against you, or tax liens levied by a government authority.  Your credit file contains public records that are too recent.  All public records can have a significant negative impact on your credit score.
88.tip: Pay all bills on-time and satisfy all judgments.  The impact that negative items such as public records have on your credit score will diminish over time.

90.label: Too few discharged bankruptcies
90.description: You have a bankruptcy on your credit report that has not been discharged.
90.tip: Complete your bankruptcy plan to have your debts discharged.Â¾ The impact on your credit score from the bankruptcy will diminish over time.

93.label: The worst status on your student loan accounts is delinquent or derogatory
93.description: Your credit file is showing a student loan with a payment that was at least 30 days late and/or on which a lender has reported a derogatory status.  Late payments are a proven indicator of increased risk.  People with late payments are at risk of being overextended, putting existing credit with lenders at risk.
93.tip: Paying bills on time every month is important to maintaining a good credit score.  If you remain behind with any payments, bring them current as soon as possible, and then make future payments on time.  Over time, this will have a positive impact on your score.

94.label: The balance amount paid down on your open student loan accounts is too low
94.description: The amount that has been paid down on your open student loan accounts is low.  People who haven\'t paid down much of their student loan account balances are higher credit risks than people who have.
94.tip: As monthly student loan account payments are made, a portion of the outstanding balance is reduced, benefitting your score.  Whenever possible, further pay down balances on your accounts.  Over time, this will also have a positive impact on your score.

95.label: You have too many collection agency accounts that are unpaid
95.description: Some collection agencies report account information to credit bureaus just like lenders do.  Your credit file has too many accounts that have been sent to a collection agency and remain unpaid.  Unpaid collection accounts in your file can have a significant negative impact on your credit score.
95.tip: Satisfy all collection accounts and pay all other accounts on time each month.  The impact that negative items such as collections accounts have on your credit score will diminish over time.

96.label: The total you owe on collection agency accounts is high
96.description: Some collection agencies report account information to credit bureaus just like lenders do.  Your credit file indicates the amount of money you owe to collection agencies is high.  Unpaid collection accounts in your file can have a significant negative impact on your credit score.
96.tip: Satisfy all collection accounts and pay all other accounts on time each month.  The impact that negative items such as collections accounts have on your credit score will diminish over time.

97.label: You have too few credit accounts
97.description: The VantageScore credit score model relies on information in your credit files at the three national credit reporting companies (Equifax, Experian and TransUnion) to generate your score.  Your credit file does not have enough credit behavior information about your loans.  A mix of different types of open and active credit accounts can have a positive impact on your credit score.
97.tip: Maintaining open and active credit accounts in good standing can help improve your credit score.

98.label: There is a bankruptcy on your credit report
98.description: Bankruptcy is a proven indicator of risk with future payments and causes a significant drop to your credit score over an extended period of time.
98.tip: Make all future payments on time.  The impact on your credit score from the bankruptcy will diminish over time.

P04.label: The balances on your accounts are not too high compared to loan limits
P04.description: Your balances are not too high compared to the loan amounts, which causes your score to improve.
P04.tip: Keep low balances on your accounts; this will benefit your score.

P05.label: There are no or only a few recent delinquencies on your accounts
P05.description: A delinquency is a payment that was made 30 or more days late. You have had no or very few delinquencies recently which has caused your score to improve.
P05.tip: Keep paying bills on time every month since it is important for maintaining a good credit score. If you remain behind with any payments, bring them current as soon as possible, and then make future payments on time. Over time, this will have a positive impact on your score.

P06.label: You have few or no accounts that were opened recently
P06.description: None or only a few of your accounts were recently opened. As a result, your history of credit management performance is enough to demonstrate responsible behavior.
P06.tip: Keep using your existing credit responsibly and make your payments on time. Your credit score will benefit as you make payments on time and manage the accounts in a responsible fashion. Manage your credit wisely by planning ahead for your credit needs and avoid applying for more credit than you need.

P07.label: You have either no or few delinquent or derogatory accounts
P07.description: Paying your bills on time improves your score. You have paid all or nearly all of your bills on time.
P07.tip: Keep paying bills on time every month since it is important to maintaining a good credit score. If you remain behind with any payments, bring them current as soon as possible, and then make future payments on time.

P08.label: One or more of your accounts were paid on time in recent months
P08.description: Paying your bills on time improves your score. Recently at least one of your accounts was paid on time.
P08.tip: Keep paying bills on time every month since it is important to maintaining a good credit score. If you remain behind with any payments, bring them current as soon as possible, and then make future payments on time.

P09.label: None of your accounts have a severe delinquency or a derogatory status
P09.description: Paying your bills on time improves your score. You have paid all your accounts on time or no more than 30 days late.
P09.tip: Keep paying bills on time every month since it is important to maintaining a good credit score. If you remain behind with any payments, bring them current as soon as possible, and then make future payments on time.

P10.label: One or more of your accounts have been paid on time
P10.description: Paying your bills on time improves your score. At least one of your accounts has no late payments.
P10.tip: Keep paying bills on time every month since it is important to maintaining a good credit score. If you remain behind with any payments, bring them current as soon as possible, and then make future payments on time.

P11.label: You have few or no accounts with delinquent or derogatory balances
P11.description: Paying your bills on time improves your score. At most, only a small amount of your balances is currently late.
P11.tip: Keep paying bills on time every month since it is important to maintaining a good credit score. If you remain behind with any payments, bring them current as soon as possible, and then make future payments on time.

P12.label: The date that you opened your oldest account is not too recent
P12.description: Your oldest account was not opened too recently. As a result, your history of credit management is enough to demonstrate responsible behavior which has improved your score.
P12.tip: Don\'t open more accounts than you actually need. Research shows that new accounts indicate greater risk. Your score will benefit as your accounts get older.

P13.label: Your most recently opened account is not too new
P13.description: Your newest account was not opened too recently. As a result, your history of credit management is enough to demonstrate responsible behavior which has improved your score.
P13.tip: Don\'t open more accounts than you actually need. Research shows that new accounts indicate greater risk. Your score will benefit as your accounts get older.

P14.label: Your credit file contains enough information about your use of credit
P14.description: A credit file with sufficient accounts and credit history reflects more experience in handling credit. More experience can have a positive impact on your score.
P14.tip: Maintaining open and active credit accounts in good standing can help improve your credit score.

P15.label: None of your accounts have a recent delinquency or a derogatory status
P15.description: A delinquency or derogatory is a payment that was made at least 30 or more days late. Recently you have paid all of your accounts on time which has caused your score to improve.
P15.tip: Keep paying bills on time every month since it is important to maintaining a good credit score. If you remain behind with any payments, bring them current as soon as possible, and then make future payments on time.

P16.label: The total of all balances on your open accounts is not too high
P16.description: The total of your balances on your open accounts, compared to the loan amounts, is not too high which has caused your score to improve.
P16.tip: Keep low balances on your accounts; this will benefit your score.

P17.label: Balances on prior delinquent accounts not too high compared to loan amts
P17.description: Keeping low balances and paying your accounts on time can improve your score. The balances on accounts, that were previously paid late, are now low compared to the loan amount or credit limit.
P17.tip: Keep paying bills on time every month since it is important to maintaining a good credit score. If you remain behind with any payments, bring them current as soon as possible, and then make future payments on time.

P18.label: Total of balances on accts never late not too high compared to loan amts
P18.description: Your balances on loans that you have paid on time, compared to the loan amounts, are not too high which has caused your score to improve.
P18.tip: Keep low balances on your accounts; this will benefit your score.

Because you have no open accounts, your credit file does not contain enough information about your use of credit. A mix of different types of open and active credit accounts can have a positive impact on your score.
P21.tip: Maintaining open and active credit accounts in good standing can help improve your credit score.

Because you have no open accounts, your credit file does not contain enough information about your use of credit. A mix of different types of open and active credit accounts can have a positive impact on your score.

P29.label: Few or none of your open bankcard or revolving accounts has a balance
P29.description: Bankcard accounts include credit cards and charge cards from a bank and are frequently revolving accounts. Revolving accounts allow you to carry a balance and your monthly payment will vary, based on the amount of your balance. Keeping low balances can improve your score. The balances on your bankcard and revolving accounts are low.
P29.tip: Keep low balances on your accounts; this will benefit your score.

P30.label: One or more of your bankcard or revolving accounts has a high limit
P30.description: Bankcard accounts include credit cards and charge cards from a bank and are frequently revolving accounts. Revolving accounts allow you to carry a balance and your monthly payment will vary, based on the amount of your balance. Having bankcard or revolving accounts with high credit limits indicates that you have high availability of credit, improving your score.
P30.tip: Keep using your existing credit responsibly. Your credit score will benefit as you manage the accounts in a responsible fashion. Manage your credit wisely by planning ahead for your credit needs and avoid applying for more credit than you need.

P31.label: Few or none of your bankcard or revolving accounts was opened recently
P31.description: Bankcard accounts include credit cards and charge cards from a bank and are frequently revolving accounts. Revolving accounts allow you to carry a balance and your monthly payment will vary, based on the amount of your balance. None or only a few of your bankcard or revolving accounts were recently opened. As a result, your history of credit management is enough to demonstrate responsible behavior.
P31.tip: Keep using your existing credit responsibly and make your payments on time. Your credit score will benefit as you make payments on time and manage the accounts in a responsible fashion. Manage your credit wisely by planning ahead for your credit needs and avoid applying for more credit than you need.

You have paid all your bankcard or revolving accounts on time or no more than 30 days late.

P63.tip: Maintaining open and active credit accounts in good standing can help improve your credit score.

P64.label: No open first mortgage accounts in your credit file
P64.description: The VantageScore credit score model relies on information in your credit files at the three national credit reporting companies (Equifax, Experian and TransUnion) to generate your score. A mix of different types of open and active credit accounts, including first mortgage accounts, can have a positive impact on your score.
P64.tip: Maintaining open and active credit accounts in good standing can help improve your credit score.

P65.label: Lack of sufficient relevant first mortgage account information
P65.description: The VantageScore credit score model relies on information in your credit files at the three national credit reporting companies (Equifax, Experian and TransUnion) to generate your score. A mix of different types of open and active credit accounts, including first mortgage accounts, can have a positive impact on your score.
P65.tip: Maintaining open and active credit accounts in good standing can help improve your credit score.

P66.label: Balances on open auto accounts are not too high compared to loan amounts
P66.description: Your balances on auto accounts are not too high compared to the original loan amounts, which causes your score to improve.
P66.tip: Keep low balances on your accounts; this will benefit your score.

P68.label: No open auto accounts in your credit file
P68.description: The VantageScore credit score model relies on information in your credit files at the three national credit reporting companies (Equifax, Experian and TransUnion) to generate your score. A mix of different types of open and active credit accounts, including auto accounts, can have a positive impact on your score.
P68.tip: Maintaining open and active credit accounts in good standing can help improve your credit score.

P69.label: Lack of sufficient relevant auto account information
P69.description: The VantageScore credit score model relies on information in your credit files at the three national credit reporting companies (Equifax, Experian and TransUnion) to generate your score. A mix of different types of open and active credit accounts, including auto accounts, can have a positive impact on your score.
P69.tip: Maintaining open and active credit accounts in good standing can help improve your credit score.

P70.label: No open personal installment loans in your credit file
P70.description: The VantageScore credit score model relies on information in your credit files at the three national credit reporting companies (Equifax, Experian and TransUnion) to generate your score. A mix of different types of open and active credit accounts, including personal installment accounts, can have a positive impact on your score.
P70.tip: Maintaining open and active credit accounts in good standing can help improve your credit score.

P71.label: One or more of your installment accounts has been paid on time
P71.description: An installment account is one with a fixed monthly payment for the life of the loan. Auto loans and student loans are common examples of installment loans. Paying your bills on time improves your score. At least one of your installment accounts was paid on time.
P71.tip: Keep paying bills on time every month since it is important to maintaining a good credit score. If you remain behind with any payments, bring them current as soon as possible, and then make future payments on time.

P72.label: Few or no installment accts with delinquent or derogatory payment status
P72.description: An installment account is one with a fixed monthly payment for the life of the loan. Auto loans and student loans are common examples of installment loans. Paying your bills on time improves your score. You have paid all your installment loans on time or no more than 30 days late.
P72.tip: Keep paying bills on time every month since it is important to maintaining a good credit score. If you remain behind with any payments, bring them current as soon as possible, and then make future payments on time.

P73.label: No installment accounts with a severe delinquency or derogatory status
P73.description: An installment account is one with a fixed monthly payment for the life of the loan. Auto loans and student loans are common examples of installment loans. Paying your bills on time improves your score. You have paid all your installment accounts on time or no more than 30 days late.
P73.tip: Keep paying bills on time every month since it is important to maintaining a good credit score. If you remain behind with any payments, bring them current as soon as possible, and then make future payments on time.

P74.label: Amount of balance paid down on open installment accounts is not too low
P74.description: An installment account is one with a fixed monthly payment for the life of the loan. Auto loans and student loans are common examples of installment loans. The amount that has been paid down on your open installment accounts is high. Paying down a high amount of your installment loans increases your score.
P74.tip: As monthly installment account payments are made, a portion of the outstanding principal balance is reduced, benefitting your score. Whenever possible, further pay down balances on your accounts. Over time this will also have a positive impact on your score.

P75.label: Your most recently opened installment account is not too new
P75.description: An installment account is one with a fixed monthly payment for the life of the loan. Auto loans and student loans are common examples of installment loans. Your newest installment account was not opened too recently. As a result, your history of credit management is enough to demonstrate responsible behavior which has improved your score.
P75.tip: Don\'t open more accounts than you actually need. Research shows that new accounts indicate greater risk. Your score will benefit as your accounts get older.

P76.label: Your credit file has enough history on your use of installment loans
P76.description: An installment account is one with a fixed monthly payment for the life of the loan. Auto loans and student loans are common examples of installment loans. A credit file with sufficient accounts and credit history, including installment loans, reflects more experience in handling credit. More experience can have a positive impact on your score.
P76.tip: Maintaining open and active credit accounts in good standing can help improve your credit score.

P77.label: Newest delinquent/derogatory status on installment accts not too recent
P77.description: An installment account is one with a fixed monthly payment for the life of the loan. Auto loans and student loans are common examples of installment loans. You have an installment account that had a late payment or on which a lender has reported a derogatory status. However, your credit file shows that this event did not occur too recently, having some positive impact on your score.
P77.tip: Keep paying bills on time every month since it is important to maintaining a good credit score. If you remain behind with any payments, bring them current as soon as possible, and then make future payments on time.

P78.label: Installment account balances not too high compared to loan amounts
P78.description: An installment account is one with a fixed monthly payment for the life of the loan. Auto loans and student loans are common examples of installment loans. Your balances on installment accounts are not too high compared to the original loan amounts, which causes your score to improve.
P78.tip: Keep low balances on your accounts; this will benefit your score.

P79.label: You have few or no recent delinquencies on your installment accounts
P79.description: An installment account is one with a fixed monthly payment for the life of the loan. Auto loans and student loans are common examples of installment loans. A delinquency is a payment that was made 30 or more days late. You have had no or very few delinquencies recently on your installment accounts, which has caused your score to improve.
P79.tip: Keep paying bills on time every month since it is important for maintaining a good credit score. If you remain behind with any payments, bring them current as soon as possible, and then make future payments on time. Over time, this will have a positive impact on your score.

P81.label: No open installment accounts in your credit file
P81.description: The VantageScore credit score model relies on information in your credit files at the three national credit reporting companies (Equifax, Experian and TransUnion) to generate your score. A mix of different types of open and active credit accounts, including installment accounts, can have a positive impact on your score.
P81.tip: Maintaining open and active credit accounts in good standing can help improve your credit score.

P83.label: Lack of sufficient relevant installment account information
P83.description: The VantageScore credit score model relies on information in your credit files at the three national credit reporting companies (Equifax, Experian and TransUnion) to generate your score. A mix of different types of open and active credit accounts, including installment accounts, can have a positive impact on your score.
P83.tip: Maintaining open and active credit accounts in good standing can help improve your credit score.

P85.label: You have few or no inquiries on your credit report
P85.description: If a lender runs a credit check when you apply for credit, an inquiry is reported to the credit bureaus. This can lower your score a small amount, typically by 10 to 20 points. The VantageScore credit score model takes rate shopping, e.g., for a mortgage or car loan, into consideration. All inquiries for mortgages, auto loans and major credit cards that appear in your credit file within a 14-day window are counted as a single inquiry. Another time inquiries never count against your score is when you check your own credit or obtain your own score. You have no inquiries or a low number of inquiries on your credit report, which increases your score.
P85.tip: Apply for credit only when you need it. If you are approved for credit, the small score drop from making an inquiry will disappear within a short time and the score will quickly benefit if you make on-time payments and manage your new account in a responsible fashion.

P86.label: You have few or no derogatory public records on your credit report
P86.description: Public records include information filed or recorded by local, state, federal or other government agencies that is available to the general public. The types of public records that can affect your score include legal judgments against you and tax liens levied by a government authority. You have few or no public records on your credit report, which increases your score.
P86.tip: Pay all bills on-time and satisfy all judgments. The impact that negative items such as public records have on your credit score will diminish over time.

P87.label: You have few or no unsatisfied public records on your credit report
P87.description: Public records include information filed or recorded by local, state, federal or other government agencies that is available to the general public. The types of public records that can affect your score include legal judgments against you and tax liens levied by a government authority. You have few or no public records on your credit report, which increases your score.
P87.tip: Pay all bills on-time and satisfy all judgments. The impact that negative items such as public records have on your credit score will diminish over time.

P88.label: You have no recent derogatory public records on your credit report
P88.description: Public records include information filed or recorded by local, state, federal or other government agencies that is available to the general public. The types of public records that can affect your score include legal judgments against you and tax liens levied by a government authority. You have few or no public records on your credit report, which increases your score.
P88.tip: Pay all bills on-time and satisfy all judgments. The impact that negative items such as public records have on your credit score will diminish over time.

P90.label: You have one or more discharged bankruptcies
P90.description: You have one or more bankruptcies on your credit report. However, they have been discharged.
P90.tip: Make all future payments on time. The impact on your credit score from the bankruptcy will diminish over time.

P92.label: No open student loan accounts in your credit file
P92.description: The VantageScore credit score model relies on information in your credit files at the three national credit reporting companies (Equifax, Experian and TransUnion) to generate your score. A mix of different types of open and active credit accounts, including student loan accounts, can have a positive impact on your score.
P92.tip: Maintaining open and active credit accounts in good standing can help improve your credit score.

P93.label: No student loan accounts with a severe delinquency or derogatory status
P93.description: Paying your bills on time improves your score. You have paid all your student loans on time or no more than 30 days late.
P93.tip: Keep paying bills on time every month since it is important for maintaining a good credit score. If you remain behind with any payments, bring them current as soon as possible, and then make future payments on time. Over time, this will have a positive impact on your score.

P94.label: Amount of balance paid down on open student loan accounts is not too low
P94.description: The amount that has been paid down on your open student loan accounts is high. Paying down a high amount of your student loans increases your score.
P94.tip: As monthly student loan account payments are made, a portion of the outstanding principal balance is reduced, benefitting your score. Whenever possible, further pay down balances on your accounts. Over time this will also have a positive impact on your score.

P95.label: You have few or no unpaid collection agency accounts
P95.description: Some collection agencies report account information to credit bureaus just like lenders do. Your credit file has no or few accounts that have been sent to a collection agency and remain unpaid, which increases your score.
P95.tip: Satisfy all collection accounts and pay all other accounts on time each month. The impact that negative items such as collections accounts have on your credit score will diminish over time.

P96.label: You have few or no collection agency account balances
P96.description: Some collection agencies report account information to credit bureaus just like lenders do. Your credit file has no or few accounts that have been sent to a collection agency and remain unpaid, which increases your score.
P96.tip: Satisfy all collection accounts and pay all other accounts on time each month. The impact that negative items such as collections accounts have on your credit score will diminish over time.

P98.label: There is no bankruptcy on your credit report
P98.description: You have no bankruptcy on your credit report, which increases your score.
P98.tip: Keep paying bills on time every month since it is important for maintaining a good credit score. If you remain behind with any payments, bring them current as soon as possible, and then make future payments on time. Over time, this will have a positive impact on your score.
